subject: Art
title: Painting from Photographs
description: Using photos as reference without letting them control your painting.

hook.text: Most painters use photographs as reference ‚Äî but the trap is COPYING the photo exactly. A photograph is a starting point, not a destination. The best painters use photos for information and their artistic judgment for interpretation.

buildup.text: Photo reference pitfalls: crushed shadows (lost detail), distorted perspective (lens-dependent), desaturated colors (sensors fail in low light), and frozen moments (no movement or atmosphere). Cameras lie ‚Äî your painter's eye should correct.

discovery.text: Use the photo for WHAT (structure, proportions, details) but use your knowledge for HOW (color temperature, value relationships, edge quality, atmosphere). Adjust colors that the camera got wrong. Open up shadows. Enhance the mood.

twist.text: A pro technique: combine multiple photo references. Use one for composition, another for lighting, a third for color inspiration. No single photo is perfect ‚Äî compositing references gives you the best of each.

climax.text: Take a photograph and paint from it ‚Äî but deliberately change three things: push the color temperature (warmer or cooler), simplify the background, and adjust the focal point. Your painting will be MORE real than the photo because it's interpreted, not copied.

punchline.text: A photo captures facts. A painting captures truth. Use the photo for facts, then add your truth.

quiz.question: What is the main risk of painting from photographs?
options: Copying photo distortions (crushed shadows, desaturated colors, lens distortion) instead of interpreting with artistic judgment
